title: Testimony and Trust: When to Believe Others
description: One-minute skill: Testimony and Trust: When to Believe Others.

hook.text: You believe the Earth orbits the Sun. Have you verified it yourself? No. You trust scientists.

buildup.text: Testimony â€“ information from others â€“ is our primary knowledge source.

discovery.text: Reliable testimony comes from credible sources, corroborated accounts, and consistent track records.

twist.text: But expertise in one field doesn't transfer. A Nobel physicist's opinion on economics deserves no special weight.

climax.text: The key question: does this person have both the expertise AND the incentive alignment to tell the truth?

punchline.text: Trust isn't binary. It's calibrated to track record and incentives.

quiz.question: What makes testimony reliable?
options: Credibility, corroboration, and consistent track records
